abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, and the
            institutional development impacts substantial. The project
            successfully demonstrated that a comprehensive development
            of small watersheds, integrating crop and livestock, as a
            means to rehabilitate infertile soils, can be widely
            applied, even further refined if needed, on similar,
            under-fertilized red soil areas. Lessons of success, namely
            feature, the development, and application of comprehensive
            technical standards; adequate training of both project staff
            and farmers; selection of capable, and motivated
            beneficiaries; and, a timely availability of counterpart
            funding. Moreover, production diversification was a
            contributing factor, particularly in minimizing risks of
            weather-related crop-damage: diversifying orchard crops with
            deciduous fruits, i.e., plum, pear, and peach, or citrus
            varieties, as well as lychee, longan, and loquat, gave
            positive results, following the careful site selection of
            frost-susceptible crops. The need for diversification is
            reinforced by the volatility of agricultural market prices;
            however, production marketing, particularly of high-value
            fruit output, requires strengthening of market information
            systems, and assistance to growers in setting-up marketing
            groups. While investments in agro-processing enterprises
            (Government owned/operated) has been generally unsuccessful,
            by contrast, private participation - as shown by the project
            - provided the needed influx in management skills, and
            working capital, which lead to profitable enterprises.
